Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Karrikin and strigolactone signaling mechanisms in Arabidopsis
Award.AbstractNarration:
DAVID C NELSON
PROPOSAL IOS-1350561
CAREER: Karrikin and strigolactone signaling mechanisms in Arabidopsis

Karrikins are a recently discovered class of compounds found in smoke that activate germination of many plant species after fire. Strigolactones comprise a family of plant hormones that regulate shoot branching, root architecture, and cambial growth. Strigolactones also trigger germination of the highly destructive parasitic weeds, broomrape and witchweed, and promote symbiotic associations with arbuscular mycorrhizal fungi. Understanding the molecular mechanisms by which karrikins and strigolactones control plant growth may enable a new wave of innovation in crop development and weed control.

Plants recognize both karrikins and strigolactones through a genetic pathway that requires the F-box protein MAX2. F-box proteins have central roles in several plant hormone signaling systems, and act by targeting specific protein substrates for degradation. The targets of MAX2 have long remained elusive and as such represent a critical roadblock to understanding the mechanism of karrikin and strigolactone signaling. A genetic screen has now led to the identification of a candidate target, SUPPRESSOR OF MAX2 1 (SMAX1), which regulates seed germination and seedling growth. SMAX1 is a member of an uncharacterized family of eight genes in the model plant Arabidopsis thaliana. In this project genetic and biochemical approaches will be used to determine 1) how other genes in the SMAX1 family contribute to plant development; 2) the molecular function and regulation of SMAX1 protein; and 3) the protein interacting partners of SMAX1 and MAX2. These experiments will reveal how the SMAX1 family acts in karrikin and strigolactone signaling and whether SMAX1 is a target of MAX2.

A postdoctoral researcher,graduate student, and several undergraduates will be trained for careers in science-related fields. Two projects will be initiated to improve undergraduate retention in science-related careers and enhance K-12 STEM education. The discoveries from this project will be disseminated through publications in peer-reviewed journals and presentations at scientific conferences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

Karrikins are chemicals found in smoke that regulate plant growth and stimulate germination of many species that emerge after fire. Strigolactones are plant hormones that control many aspects of development. Strigolactones are also exuded into soil. Some parasitic plants use strigolactones to know when to germinate and attack a nearby host, which can devastate crops.

 

This project sought to understand how plants sense and respond to karrikins and strigolactones, which could enable agricultural improvements. Prior work had identified three genes needed for karrikin and strigolactone responses: KAI2 and D14, which were likely receptors, and MAX2, which was expected to target specific proteins for degradation after receptor activation. The targets remained a crucial missing piece of the puzzle. We had identified SMAX1 and seven similar SMXL proteins as potential targets. The primary aims of this project were to determine the roles of SMAX1/SMXLs in plant development, understand how SMAX1 protein works and how it is regulated, and investigate how SMAX1/SMXLs interact with other proteins to control growth.

 

We discovered that SMAX1 and SMXL2 are karrikin pathway targets that control germination, seedling growth, and leaf shape. SMXL6, SMXL7, and SMXL8 are strigolactone pathway targets that control shoot branching, lateral root growth, and leaf shape. SMXL3, SMXL4, and SMXL5 are not targeted by either pathway, but regulate root development and may affect strigolactone pathway activity. KAI2 is important for drought tolerance, and D14 is less so. SMAX1 is targeted for degradation by MAX2-KAI2. In some cases, D14 can also trigger SMAX1 degradation. SMAX1 is highly unstable. We identified the parts of the SMAX1 protein that mediate its interaction with KAI2, location in the cell, degradation by MAX2, and ability to regulate growth. SMAX1 and SMXLs likely interact with each other, and with proteins that suppress transcription. We also discovered that extra copies of KAI2 had become strigolactone receptors in parasitic plants, enabling host detection. We found that KAI2 is unlikely to perceive karrikins directly. Instead, it may sense an unknown karrikin derivative and an unknown plant hormone. We investigated how strigolactone perception evolved from KAI2 derivatives across land plants, ranging from mosses to parasites.

 

It is clear that karrikin and strigolactone pathways are highly similar, with a shared evolutionary origin. Our work raises questions of how these pathways achieve signaling fidelity and how their distinct functions evolved. Identification of strigolactone receptors in parasites has catalyzed searches for better chemicals to control these weeds. Identifying the unknown hormone perceived by KAI2 has become a major goal of this field.

 

Broader Impacts

This project contributed to the development of a diverse and globally competitive STEM workforce. Thirteen undergraduate researchers participated in this project, of which seven were supported by summer REU funds. Four undergraduates entered medical/osteopathic school and two will enter graduate programs. Two graduate students were trained and earned PhD degrees. One is faculty at Berry College and the other is pursuing postdoctoral training. Four postdoctoral researchers were trained. One is faculty at Mercer University, one is employed in biotechnology industry, one is a staff researcher at Texas Woman's University, and one is continuing training. Four technicians were also trained. Among these 23 trainees, 13 (57%) are women, and 8 (35%) are black or Hispanic underrepresented minorities in STEM.

 

An Undergraduate Research Award was developed to promote undergraduate contributions to scientific research and to enhance scientific self-identity. The program augmented an annual campus-wide plant biology research symposium at the University of Georgia. Awardees were mentored, expanded their scientific networks, presented their research, and were publicly recognized. This became a highly valued component of the symposium. This project provided funding and program leadership for three years, serving 22 students. The program has continued with sponsorship from the UGA Plant Center, serving 19 more students over the past three years.

 

Professional development of K-12 STEM teachers was carried out through summer Research Experiences for Teachers. Four high school teachers trained in molecular biology techniques, learned about this project's research, and developed related materials based to enhance their classroom teaching.

 

Project results were disseminated broadly. Ten peer-reviewed research articles and four review articles were published, garnering 573 citations and 285 citations, respectively. The PI gave talks at twelve international conferences, three professional symposia, 15 department seminars at other institutions, and one public symposium at a botanical garden. Undergraduate education was enhanced through an online book chapter on plant hormones and development of a free Teaching Tool in Plant Biology on the topic of parasitic plants. Teaching Tools provide peer-reviewed lecture slides, teaching notes, and a review, enabling easy implementation in biology classrooms. It has been downloaded 1050 times. Questions for the high school AP Biology exam related to this research area were developed with consultation from the PI. An interview on this award's research was published in Science News for Students, which reaches K-12 students.
